utterances: You know, ever since Priebus especially has gone, the Republican Party's institutional hold in this White House has really declined.

Dionne, thanks to both of you.

This is DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
A Belgian rider, Tom Boonen, won today's third stage of the Tour de France, but an American still holds the lead overall, David Zabriskie.
He's two seconds ahead of the most well-known cyclist from the US, Lance Armstrong.
Still, Armstrong's dominance has made it hard for other US riders to elbow into the spotlight.
But when the six-time Tour de France winner retires, several young Americans have hopes to take his place.
Eric Niiler has this report.
Armstrong hasn't won any races this year, but his performance on Saturday left no doubt as to his form.
The Texan passed his chief rival, German Jan Ullrich, in a flash.
Here's the action as called by Outdoor Life Network's Phil Liggett.
(Soundbite of Tour de France)
Armstrong has galloped across a gap of almost one minute and he could be putting Jan Ullrich out of the tour on day number one.
This is unthinkable.
Armstrong likely won't make anymore big moves until the race moves to the Alps next week.
But the real surprise is a 26-year-old from Salt Lake City, David Zabriskie, who rides for Danish Team CSC.
Zabriskie is a shy kid, who's only the third American to wear the leader's yellow jersey.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Audie Cornish and we return now to the NPR Cities Project.
The lead story today?
Well, we actually do two papers, one for Cincinnati audience, and then we're right on the border and we also have a Kentucky paper, and the lead stories are different.

In Cincinnati, the lead story is on hospitals and how--local hospitals and how they're making their ends meet and whether--we've had a lot of instances where the--an ambulance taking somebody to the hospital can't go to the nearest one and has to be sent elsewhere, sidetracked elsewhere, and that's our lead story today.
And right after that is a story about a City Councilman who's in trouble with the law.
Right.
And those are important--people have to know about those stories, certainly.
Key stories--how do you decide how much your paper is devoted to international events?
I--we are going to start more every day by saying, `What do we have locally?
The world sort of competes against local news on our page one.

Now we do have in the A section, which is the front section, a second page that's devoted daily to national and international news, labeled Nation and World, and expect a daily summary there of other headlines from around the world, as well as just the news whole--inside that A section.
It varies from day to day.
So you're going to have a summary--yeah.

So maybe a summary of world events on stories that may not be the top headlines, and then if there's something in the Middle East or some other story, Darfur, for instance, perhaps explodes, a little larger story, a little bigger story in the A section?
Right, and on any given day a story from around the world might have the legs to--and just sort of the--in our judgment an interest--general public interest to make the cut on page one.
A lot of times it depends on what's happening locally, also.
Well, how do you gauge that interest?

I think we're trying to keep up with the breaking news and--on those inside stories, but if something just lasts a little longer and begins to feel like it has more interest or more impact and then it gets a little more space and a little more play.
And the other factor is what's the local connection to an international story.
We're--have Procter & Gamble here and Procter & Gamble's growth is hinged on expanding in the world markets.
An airport that's connected to the world and international airports.
It's--a lot of business stories might drive our interest in an international story.
So are stories about globalization likely to make your paper?
About globalization ...(unintelligible)?
About the phenomenon itself, yeah.
Yes.
And what about--to what extent--you talked about the local connection.
How important is that in deciding whether or not an international story gets space?
It's sort of like any news in the paper, how the newspaper's trying to reach a general audience.
Does this story have currency with a lot of people or just a fairly narrow audience?
Procter & Gamble's involved, it's likely to affect more people.
Some things might just be quirky and interesting to a wide audience.

There's a company, for example, that sells kind of an obscure things, but sells bands that go on birds around the world, so, you know, if we were writing about that, we might take a look at what their market is and how they market globally.
But things like that.
Mm-hmm.
Let's go to the phones now.
We're talking today about getting your international news.
Where do you get it from?
How important is it to you as a consumer of news?
We're also talking to people in the news business about whether or not it's important to their news organization, how they gather the news, and what perspective we tell the news from.
Cindy is on the line from Akron, Ohio.
Hi, Cindy.
Hi.
You have a question for us?
You know what?
Every day I--since September 11th, I turn on the TV and I listen to a thousand million cable channels and try to get something.
So finally my paper in Akron is The Akron Beacon Journal.
You're talking to Cincinnati.
He knows who--knows where you're talking to.
I finally got The New York Times daily during the week.
I read everything that they report globally, and when I can't find what I need, I go online to BBC.
Well, tell me, Cindy, let me ask you--interrupt you for a moment and ask you what it is you think you need.
What are you looking for in international news that you don't seem to be finding?
Well, I think it's important.
We all talk about, you know, why do they hate us.
I think we need to understand the world, and until we understand the depth of poverty and the depth of hopelessness that most of these people feel in Africa.
We support a lot of regimes because of oil.
These people are living in real poverty.
We do not know what that means.
I support through an organization a little girl in India.
This child would probably be, I don't know, farmed out or something.
I don't know.
Cindy, I want to get a response, because you said a few things that I think would be very interesting, and I'd like to have Mark Neikirk respond to them, the managing editor at The Cincinnati Post.
Thank you very much for your call.
Number one, are you worried about losing readers like Cindy?
Well, we worry about losing readers, sure.
I do also think that people in--realistically now we know that people look online for news.
Obviously we have at every newspaper an online presence.
But it's a little like before the Internet, if you want to know about the world, you read the newspaper, but you also go to the library.
And it's--every citizen has a responsibility to look more than one place.
It's certain--the news is event driven, and we all learned a lot more about the area hit by the tsunami than we did know about that area before that weather event.
That forces us, draws our attention to an area, and we begin to look at things.
(SOUNDBITE OF THEME)
This question that Mark has just raised, one of them is about sources, about people sort of being free to and encouraged to search out other sources to slake their needs for news.
What kind of sources are out there?
You've written extensively on the globalization of media.
Are there a variety of sources?
Sure.
The first thought that comes to my mind when listening to Mark is, in a way, how things haven't changed so much.

Mark didn't expressly refer to the wire services, but I would bet that Associated Press is going to be a very significant source of both national and international news for Mark, and AP is a cooperative of approximately 1,500 daily US newspapers, and it is a very significant source of news for them, for most of them.
Most of them don't have--don't field their own correspondents in overseas countries, or if they do, just a very small number.
So one thing I take from Mark is that in this respect, globalization or not, at the local level, things don't seem to have changed that much.

So secondly, the second thought I have is that, as Mark rightly says, there are many more sources in--that we can access through the Web, so that has changed, that we do have--as news consumers, we have access to--I'm tempted to say an infinitely broader range of sources than we used to.
Probably...
Is it--is there a problem of vetting and credibility, though?
Yes, that's one issue.
The--many of these sources that we can access over the Internet do not have the branded, if you like, credibility and trustworthiness that people often attribute to the mainstream media.
But we can also use the Internet wisely to access other brand-name sources.
We could use it to access stories from Reuters, for example, or Bloomberg or even Agence France-Presse, which is the French-language--well, not only French language, but the...
French-based.
...French international agency.

Well, I want to talk more about this, about the sources, where they come from, their cultural biases, if there are any, and whether or not we can trust the news we get abroad, and if it's becoming more global.
We'll take your phone calls at (800) 989-8255.
This is part of Think Global, public radio's week of special coverage.
I'm Frank Stasio.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
(Soundbite of music)
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Frank Stasio in Washington, sitting in for Neal Conan.
How global is your news?
Is your primary source of information--the local paper, television, the Internet, NPR--giving you the global coverage you need?
You can give us a call at (800) 989-TALK or send us an e-mail at this address, totn@npr.org.
Our guest is Oliver Boyd-Barrett, professor of communications at California State University in Pomona, California, author of the book ""The Globalization of News.
And before the break we were talking about the sources of news.
Most of the sources--in fact, all of the sources you mentioned were Western-based sources.
These are sources in Western countries.
If I'm looking for news about other cultures, can I trust that a bias hasn't been worked into those sources?
Well, I think that that is a big question, Frank.

Interestingly, it's been a question that's been around for a long time, because before we had organizations like CNN and BBC World, we had the wire services--just mentioned Associated Press--we had Reuters, Agence France-Presse, and these are organizations that go back more or less directly to the mid 19th century, and almost from the days that those organizations became powerful as gatherers of news around the world and as sellers of news around the world, there were worries in--from different countries that these sources might be biased.
We might want to say--today we might want to say that they--the worry was that they were too ethnocentric in the take that they had on the world.

And so quite frequently, from time to time, you had attempts to counter the influence of the Reuters and the Associated Presses with the development of new forms of collaboration based in non-Western countries.
Not many of those succeeded.
Actually, originally UP, the--that was the organization that--the forerunner to UPI.
UP was a kind of resister to what was then called the news cartel.
This is the end--at the beginning of the 20th century.
And then later on, Associated Press withdrew from the cartel and it, too, became--joined this radical group saying, you know, `We're fed up with a world news flow that's dominated by these Europeans.
We want our own voice.
And--yeah.
Sorry, Frank.
Go ahead.
